definition: value/(to be) worth/to happen to/to be on duty
coin/money/CL:筆|笔[bi3]/unit of weight, one tenth of a tael 兩|两[liang3]

sentences.english: Some day his pictures will be worth more than all you have in your shop.
sentences.chinese: 有一天，他的畫會比你店裏所有的一切還值錢。

sentences.english: Because $10 today is not more valuable than $9 a few decades ago.
sentences.chinese: 因爲今天的10美元並不比幾十年前的9美元值錢。

sentences.english: Madam, it's not worth to take risk, your life is precious.
sentences.chinese: 夫人，划不來嘛，你的命很值錢的。

sentences.english: At times, kingfisher feathers have achieved the status of gemstones, silk, and spices.
sentences.chinese: 有的時候，翠鳥的羽毛和寶石，絲綢，香料一樣值錢。

sentences.english: Watermelons in Beijing in the summer are a dime a dozen.
sentences.chinese: 北京的夏天，西瓜多得根本不值錢了。

sentences.english: In the family all was worth the money all buys.
sentences.chinese: 家裏所有值錢的全買了。

sentences.english: I never said you were worthless. What I said was you’re not worth your weight in gold.
The burglar moused about for valuables.
sentences.chinese: 竊賊在左尋右找值錢的東西。

sentences.english: They plundered all the valuable things they could find.
sentences.chinese: 他們搶劫的所有能找到的值錢東西。

sentences.english: He found in India that subalterns were two a penny and invited nowhere.
sentences.chinese: 和少尉軍官多得不值錢，在哪兒也不會成爲座上客。

sentences.english: The wood chair Father bought yesterday is valuable.
sentences.chinese: 爸爸昨天買的那把木椅很值錢。

sentences.english: Youth is fortune. But, without struggle it is just unvalued.
sentences.chinese: 年輕是本錢，但不努力就不值錢。

sentences.english: In dogs, purebreds are valuable. How about people?
Stealing the most valuable goods is autocycle .
sentences.chinese: 偷過最值錢的物品是摩托車。

sentences.english: So the stamp with the pyramid was valuable after all?
sentences.chinese: 所以這張埃及郵票還是挺值錢的吧？

sentences.english: Breaking into the palaces, they snatched everything of value.
sentences.chinese: 他們闖進皇宮，把值錢的東西都搶跑了。

definition: coin/money/CL:筆|笔[bi3]/unit of weight, one tenth of a tael 兩|两[liang3]
to seem/to appear/(in a negative or interrogative sentence) to be sure
to sell/to betray/to spare no effort/to show off or flaunt
adornment/to adorn/dress/clothing/costume (of an actor in a play)/to play a role/to pretend/to install/to fix/to wrap (sth in a bag)/to load/to pack
high denomination of banknotes or coins/lots of money/a big sum (e.g. a bribe)
at the minimum/at the very least
